name: irrigation, sprinkler | irrigation | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/21040/documentation

This dataset represents the sprinkler irrigation in Switzerland with a 75% irrigation efficieny. The inventory includes the water pumping of ground water and surface water, as well as the infrastructure. The water supplied to the plants (1m3) and the water evaporated or infiltrated shall be included in the crop production datasets.

This dataset starts with pumping water from wells and water bodies.

This dataset ends with delivering water to the plant and includes the water pumping, energy use, infrastructure, but not the water emissions of irrigation (shall be included in the crop production dataset).
category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/01:Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities/016:Support activities to agriculture and post-harvest crop activities/0161:Support activities for crop production

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The data was collected for the given time range.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: This dataset contains Swiss specific data and general, technology specific information.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Sprinkler irrigation is a method of applying irrigation water similar to natural rainfall. Water is distributed through a system of pipes usually by pumping. It is then sprayed into the air through sprinklers so that it breaks up into small water drops which fall to the ground. The pump supply system, sprinklers and operating conditions must be designed to enable a uniform application of water.;This method is suited for most row, field and tree crops and water can be sprayed over or under the crop. Sprinklers are best suited to sandy soils with high infiltration rates although they are adaptable to most soils, nevertheless, are not suitable for soils which easily form a crust.;A good clean supply of water, free of suspended sediments, is require to avoid problems of sprinkler nozzle blockage and spoiling the crop by coating it with sediment (FAO, 1985b)
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: The material input are based on the FAO example of hose-move sprinkler irrigation design for cotton (FAO, 2007). The data on water sources, irrigation efficiency and energy demand is compiled based on different data sources, incluiding the Global Map of Irrigation Areas (GMIA), FAO-AQUASTAT libary, national census reports and other internacional organizations or statistical services.

exchanges.description: Calculated value. A tractor is assumed to install the sprinkler irrigation system, with an average diesel consumption of 3.78kg/ha (4 times*0.25ha*4.5l/ha*0.83 kg/l), based on ecoinvent (Nemecek & K채gi, 2007). The energy consumption of levelling the field is assumed to be included in the energy use for field preparation, included in the crop production dataset.

defaultProvider.category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/01:Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities/016:Support activities to agriculture and post-harvest crop activities/0161:Support activities for crop production

exchanges.description: Calculated value based on literature values. The material input are based on the FAO example of hose-move sprinkler irrigation design for cotton (FAO, 2007). The weight per m3 of water is calculated based on the lifespan of the equipment and the amount of water irrigated per ha and year. The lifespan for the distribution network is assumed to be ten years and the head control unit 20 years. The irrigation system is assumed to be functional during 7h per shift with 6 shifts (sprinkler positions) and an irrigation interval of 2 weeks. The total irrigation time per year is 1095 hours and the system discharge is 36 m3 of water per hour (FAO, 2007). FAO. (2007). Handbook of pressurized irrigation techniques. Rome, Italy
